Authors:
Prakash Vijayamma Ramakrishnan Nair, Tonya Wiechel, Nigel
Crump, Paul W.J. Taylor
Title:
Taxonomy and pathogenicity of Verticillium species infecting
potatoes in South East Australia
Abstract:
Validation of the taxonomy of the Verticillium species
involved in Verticillium wilt of potato in South East Australia was
confirmed based on traditional morphological characters and multigene
phylogeny. Although V. dahliae was the predominant species; V.
albo-atrum was identified from the vascular tissue of seed tubers from
Victoria and Tasmania, which was the first report of this pathogen from
potato in Australia for 40 years. Multigene phylogeny based on gene
sequence comparison of internal transcribed spacer region (ITS), partial
β-tubulin and elongation factor 1-alpha (EF1-α), showed that there was
very little gene diversity within V. dahliae potato isolates, V.
albo-atrum was phylogeneticaly related to V. dahliae, and that the
isolates of V. dahliae from tomato and strawberry were genetically
similar to isolates from potato. Pathogenicity studies on potato
(susceptible cv Shepody and moderately resistant cv Ranger Russet) and
eggplant (cv Black Beauty) showed that the majority of V. dahliae
isolates were highly aggressive in potato and eggplants, especially the
Tasmanian V. dahliae isolates however, some isolates were also less
aggressive. Potato cv. Shepody inoculated with V. albo-atrum and V.
tricorpus showed typical wilt symptoms however, the severity of
infection caused by V. tricorpus was substantially lower. This was the
first record of the pathogenicity of V. tricorpus on potatoes in
Australia. In eggplant, V. dahliae isolates also varied in pathogenicity
in terms of disease severity but all isolates significantly (p≤ 0.05)
reduced eggplant growth.
